Materials and methods We conducted a randomized controlled single-blind trial among adolescents. About 80 adolescents were randomized into a test or control group using block randomization. Plaque and gingival indices were recorded, and unstimulated saliva was collected at baseline and 30 days after the intervention to assess salivary antioxidants. Results About 79 adolescents completed the study out of which 45 adolescents were male. The intragroup comparison showed a significant reduction in the mean plaque and gingival indices at 30 days when compared to the baseline in both groups. There was no significant difference in the mean reduction of these indices between the test and control groups ( p p Conclusion Polyherbal toothpaste can be a suitable alternative in reducing plaque and gingivitis and enhancing salivary antioxidant levels. It deposits on the teeth and restoration alike sequentially with a complex biofilm structure interspersed with a variety of microorganisms and extracellular matrix. Hence, plaque control daily is imperative to prevent oral diseases. Self-care plaque control involves the use of a toothbrush, toothpaste, appropriate technique, frequency, and duration of toothbrushing. Brushing with toothpaste helps reduce the dependency on mechanical plaque control methods as they have antimicrobial agents and other additives that may inhibit the growth of dental plaque. However, these antimicrobial agents have potential side effects on long-term usage. There has been increased availability and acceptance of herbal-based toothpastes among the consumers which led to the introduction of newer herbal extracts and polyherbal formulations in the commercially available products. The antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant properties of these products help in maintaining oral health. The oral cavity has a complex environment with constant interactions with microorganisms and environmental irritants which increase the production of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species. 1 2 2 3 1 2 4 5 5 6 7 Assessment of MDA, NO, and total thiols (TT) is widely used in studies due to their availability, economical, and simple to measure by making the analysis easy and accurate. MDA is a well-known marker for lipid peroxidation and indicates cell damage to the membrane. The overall antioxidant capacity can be detected by TT which includes various thiol-containing compounds. NO plays a significant role in inflammation as a signaling molecule. Together, these markers help in assessing oxidative stress and antioxidant mechanisms in saliva. 8 10 Herbal products such as green tea extract, 11 12 Azadirachta indica 13 Salvadora persica 14 15 Scutellaria baicalensis 16 Carica papaya 17 Aloe vera 18 Calendula 19 Calendula Echinacea 20 25 26 Given the background, this study aims to compare the effect of polyherbal and conventional toothpaste on plaque, gingivitis, and saliva antioxidant properties after 1 month of usage. The null hypothesis was that no significant differences in the plaque, gingivitis, and saliva antioxidant levels between the toothpastes. M aterials and ethods A randomized controlled single-blind trial was conducted to compare polyherbal and conventional toothpastes among adolescents. The protocol was approved by the “Kasturba Medical College and Kasturba Hospital Institutional Ethics Committee” (IEC1: 357/2022). Prior informed consent was sought from all the adolescents. The protocol was registered with the “Clinical Trial Registry of India” (CTRI/2023/05/052169). The sample size was determined using G*Power software based on the results of previous research (effect size = 0.72). 25 Participants who had plaque and/or gingivitis of more than score 1 were willing to participate; participants above 18 years were included. Participants were excluded if they had used antibiotics, anti-inflammatories, or antioxidants in the last 7 days; had known allergies to any herbal ingredients used in the toothpaste, multiple caries, missing teeth, crowns, or large restorations; any form of tobacco habits; and had systemic diseases. A total of 294 adolescents were screened from government technical college out of which 87 were eligible and 80 consented to participate. Eighty were enrolled and randomized into test or control groups using block randomization (block size: 4) ( Fig. 1 Fig. 1: CONSORT flowchart Clinical Examination A trained, calibrated, and blinded dentist (KCP) conducted an oral examination and recorded the “Turesky, Gilmore, Glickman modification of Quigley–Hein Plaque Index” 27 28 29 30 Saliva Collection and Storage Unstimulated saliva was collected at baseline and 30 days after the intervention and was stored at −80°C without centrifugation and processed within 24 hours. Antioxidants Assay Malondialdehyde Estimation Kei Satoh method was employed for MDA which uses the thiobarbituric acid (TBA) reaction. Saliva samples were treated with trichloroacetic acid (TCA) to precipitate lipoproteins, followed by the addition of TBA in a sodium hydroxide solution. The mixture was incubated at 100°C for 20 minutes to facilitate the formation of a pink MDA–TBA complex. Subsequently, the samples were cooled, and the absorbance was assessed at 532 nm with a spectrophotometer. 31 5 −1 −1 Total Thiol Estimation Ellman's method was utilized for the estimation of TT. Saliva samples were treated with “5,5’-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoic acid)” in phosphate buffer which produces a yellow-colored “5-thio-2-nitrobenzoic acid” (TNB) compound. They were incubated at room temperature, and the absorbance of the yellow TNB compound was measured at 412 nm with a spectrophotometer. 32 −1 −1 Nitric Oxide Estimation The Griess reagent method (Sigma-Aldrich) was employed for NO estimation. In this procedure, 0.1 mL of saliva and Griess reagent were added flat-bottomed 96-well microtitration plate. It was shaken for 10 minutes at room temperature, resulting in a purple color in positive samples. The absorbance was then measured at 570 nm with a microplate reader. 33 2 Interventions The test group was given a nonfluoride toothpaste containing extracts of “cloves ( Syzygium aromaticum Cinnamomum zeylanicum Piper nigrum Mimusops elengi Quercus infectoria Cinnamomum camphora Statistical Analysis Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) software version 26 (IBM SPSS Statistics for Windows, Armonk, NY) was used to analyze the data. Twice daily toothbrushing with toothpaste is essential to minimize plaque formation and maturation. Commercially available toothpastes have a wide variety of antimicrobials and additives which can have implications over long-term usage both to the individual and environment. Hence, there is a general growing interest in the increased awareness and acceptance of herbal alternatives among consumers. Due to this, manufacturers have supplemented many herbal ingredients into oral care products. The herbal toothpaste included in this study has many such ingredients which are known to have a multitude of beneficial effects. Syzygium aromaticum C. zeylanicum 34 P. nigrum 35 37 Q. infectoria M. elengi 38 It was seen that both polyherbal and control toothpastes were effective in reducing plaque and gingivitis after 30 days of usage. Similar findings were reported from earlier studies that had single or polyherbal extracts in toothpaste concerning gingivitis, 22 39 14 24 14 22 24 39 25 20 21 23 14 22 39 The novelty in this study was the assessment of saliva antioxidant properties after the use of herbal and control toothpastes. Findings of our study suggest a protective effect by increasing the antioxidant activity of the saliva. Direct comparisons of our results with the literature were not attempted, as there were no studies that reported the salivary antioxidant activity of toothpastes. All the ingredients in the polyherbal toothpaste have been shown to have anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, and antioxidant properties which was evident in the findings of our study. MDA is a marker for lipid peroxidation and indicates cell damage of the membrane. NO plays a significant role in inflammation as a signaling molecule. The overall antioxidant capacity was measured using the TT. A decrease in MDA and NO and an increase in TT after the use of toothpaste for 30 days suggest a protective role which could be attributed to the herbal ingredients. However, a similar decrease in the control toothpaste could be due to the antimicrobial agents. Due to these properties, the polyherbal toothpaste was as effective as commercially available antimicrobial toothpaste in enhancing saliva antioxidant levels. This suggests that polyherbal toothpaste can be a suitable alternative in reducing plaque, gingivitis, plaque severity, number of bleeding sites, and enhance salivary antioxidant levels. There were limitations in our study. Participants could not be blinded as the taste and color of the toothpaste were very evident. Moreover, the control toothpaste was a commonly available over-the-counter product. Numerous salivary antioxidant assays are available, but we limited our evaluation to the most commonly available assays at our disposal due to a paucity of resources. Also, the saliva collection was done after 2 hours of brushing due to which the antioxidant levels may be underestimated. Future studies should include the long-term beneficial effects of these polyherbal toothpastes. C onclusion Polyherbal toothpaste can be a suitable alternative in reducing plaque and gingivitis and enhancing salivary antioxidant levels.
